title: The Radio Times annual party was a rowdy affair writes EPHRAIM HARDCASTLE
title_page: The Radio Times annual party was a rowdy affair writes EPHRAIM HARDCASTLE | Daily Mail Online
text:
The Radio Times annual party honouring those who have appeared on its covers, held in the expensive grandeur of Claridge’s, was a rowdy, yobby affair.
Honoured guest Sir David Attenborough had his speech drowned by the racket from boozy, broadcasting hangers-on.
So did Jeremy Paxman of University Challenge, Poldark’s Aidan Turner and guest speaker Graham Norton.
Honoured guest Sir David Attenborough had his speech drowned by the racket from boozy, broadcasting hangers-on
Says comedian Barry Cryer: ‘I’ve complained to Radio Times editor Ben Preston. It was the rudest crowd I’ve ever seen.’
BBC director-general Tony Hall should have a word with those responsible.
The Duke of York drove himself to Mile End, in London’s East End, to meet business types on Tuesday.
He covered the six miles through crowded City traffic in just 20 minutes.
My source explains: ‘Andrew, who had police outriders clearing his way, was able to pass through red lights and not worry about speed limits, finding a parking space or change for a meter when he arrived. Still, credit where it’s due!’
David Cameron’s former ‘director of strategy’ Steve Hilton is asked on Radio 4’s Today programme about the public anger surrounding Google’s enviably lax tax arrangements here.
California-based Hilton, 46, tells John Humphrys: ‘The first thing I just want to make clear for your listeners, John, just in terms of disclosure, is that my wife (Tory activist Rachel Whetstone, 47, who was godmother to Cameron’s late son, Ivan) was, for many years, a senior executive at Google.’
And Google, he added, was ‘abiding by the law then…’ Of course.
Tory activist Rachel Whetstone, 47, who was godmother to Cameron’s late son, Ivan
With husband-to-be Rupert Murdoch having reportedly bought her a £2.4million engagement ring, Texan ex-model Jerry Hall must find the media mogul a generous soul compared with her stingy former partner, rock Scrooge Sir Mick Jagger.
Pop biographer Debra Sharon Davis, who toured with the Stones, says Sir Mick was even prone to ‘micro-managing transactions with call girls’.
Trump-hairstyled Tory MP Michael Fabricant praises Waitrose’s managing director Mark Price, who has become a ‘director’ at the Cabinet Office.
Should confirmed bachelor Fabricant declare an interest? His companion, Andy Street, is managing director of John Lewis, which owns Waitrose.
RE Gerry Adams’s Little Book of Tweets, which I mentioned yesterday, a Southampton reader says: ‘It put me off my cornflakes hearing those saps on Radio 4’s Today programme going all gooey-eyed over this monster’s pathetic twitterings.
'Doubly sickening that our enforced patronage is subsidising his free publicity.’
Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby, making light on ITV’s Good Morning about parents wearing pyjamas when dropping off their children at school, says: ‘I wear a cassock in public places... who knows what I’ve got underneath it?’ Or wants to know!
Harry Potter star Daniel Radcliffe, 26, plays a floating corpse in his new film, Swiss Army Man.
